cram.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to force something into a small space
cram.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Jill crammed her clothes into the bag.
A lot of information has been crammed into this book.
cram.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: if a lot of people cram into a place or vehicle, they go into it so it is then full
cram.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We all crammed in and Pete started the car.
Thirty-six thousand spectators crammed into the stadium to see the game.
cram.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: if a lot of people cram a place, they fill it
cram.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Thousands of people crammed the mall Sunday.
cram.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to prepare yourself for an examination by learning a lot of information quickly
cram.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Sheâ€™s been cramming hard all week.
I have to cram for my chemistry test tomorrow.
